Trump dogged by cost of living crisis and Republican revolt
subhead: The US president tried to defuse Americans' dissatisfaction with the economy in a televised address on Wednesday. He continued to blame Joe Biden, but struggled to grasp the extent of the issue – provoking tensions within his own party.

title: French lawmakers fail to agree on state budget bill
EU strikes deal to provide €90 billion to Ukraine
Astoria, Zohran Mamdani's working-class New York
subhead: The victory of New York City's new mayor on November 4 was also a victory for his Queens neighborhood, Astoria, which he made the focus of his campaign. This cosmopolitan district, plagued by economic difficulties, wants to be a beacon of hope in Trump's America.

title: Brown University shooting suspect, a 48-year-old Portuguese national, found dead
subhead: The man took his own life, according to police, who linked the suspect to the shooting death in Boston of a professor two days after the tragedy at Brown. The motives behind these attacks, which left three people dead, remain unknown.

title: In Quebec, Islam is at the heart of new debates on secularism
subhead: A new bill proposes closing prayer spaces at universities, reigniting questions about the role of religion in public spaces.

title: Pina Picierno, the Italian MEP threatened by Russia for backing Ukraine
subhead: The low-profile vice president of the European Parliament has received a torrent of death threats for months. Under police protection since June, the Italian continues her fight against pro-Russian propaganda in Europe.

'It is easier to flatter the people than to serve. Therein lies the last obstacle to an RN victory in 2027'
subhead: Populism has never been stronger in France, but there is a crucial difference between flattering the people and serving them, and the Rassemblement National is currently stumbling on that divide, writes Le Monde columnist Françoise Fressoz.

title: A French farmer's distress: 'I found the first dead cow when I went to the pasture'
subhead: Near Benque, a village an hour from Toulouse, farmer Christian Lasserre discovered three carcasses on Saturday. He fears a new outbreak of lumpy skin disease and the culling of the entire herd.

title: In Paris, the number of homeless living in outdoor camps continues to rise
subhead: Outreach teams counted 663 tents in the main encampment areas of the French capital at the end of November, representing between 985 and 1,723 people. The rise is driven by a reduction in available shelter spaces and tighter restrictions on residency permits.
